data.title: Caesar Richards (abt.1737-bef.1813)
data.meta_description: Is this your ancestor? Compare DNA and explore genealogy for Caesar Richards born abt. 1737 Bryantown, Charles, Maryland died 1813 Bryantown, Charles, Maryland, USA including ancestors + descendants + 3 genealogist comments + DNA connections + more in the free family tree community.

Biography

Caesar /Richards/

Prior to import, this record was last changed 09:53 29 May 2013.

Died BEF 3 DEC 1813. Charles County, Maryland, United States of America. [3]

Residence 27 NOV 1740. Prince George’s County, Province of Maryland, Kingdom of Great Britain. Note: Father witness on Land Record of Rev. John Eversfield MD-Liber Y, Page 245. 22 AUG 1747. St Mary's County, Province of Maryland, Kingdom of Great Britain. Note: 100 acres adjoining Pheasants Neck. 1778 Port Tobacco East Hundred, Charles, Maryland, United States of America. 1783 Charles County, Maryland, United States of America. Note: Assessment: in county but not owning land. CH 4th District, General p. 10. MSA S 1161-4-12 14/547. 1798 Port Tobacco East, Charles, Maryland, United States of America. Note: tax list. [4]

Land Purchase: 29 SEP 1742. Prince George’s County, Province of Maryland, Kingdom of Great Britain. Note: Father 19 year lease to Thomas Richards on a tract of land called Carrollton, lying in PG between Monoccasi and Potomack, bounded by Willm Marshall's bounded tree, George Williams, tree, containing 113 acres called Richards Meadow recorded Prince George's Land Record Book BB I - Page 196.

SALE 30 AUG 1744. Prince George’s County, Province of Maryland, Kingdom of Great Britain. Note: Thomas Richards release and assign to Richard Clemonds of PG, Cooper, all my right to the within mentioned lease, Recorded Sep 10, 1744.

Property: AFT 30 AUG 1744. Charles County, Province of Maryland, Kingdom of Great Britain. Note: leasing from Bernard Johnson Rawlings.

Event 1775 Port Tobacco East Hundred, Charles, Province of Maryland, Kingdom of Great Britain. Note: Fidelity Oath. 11 AUG 1777. Charles County, Maryland, United States of America. Note: “committed breach of the peace on the body of Thomas Waters”. 9 MAR 1778. Charles County, Maryland, United States of America. Note: Convicted of charges of disturbing the peace of the body of Thomas Waters and John Smith.

Military Service: 23 OCT 1777. Charles County, Maryland, United States of America. Note: Caesar served as a private in the Charles County militia, 26th Battalion, Captain Benjamin Cawood's Company. Service: 30 OCT 1781. Charles County, Maryland, United States of America. Note: rendered patriot service by providing wheat to the military. Service: 2 NOV 1782. Charles County, Maryland, United States of America. Note: rendered patriot service by providing wheat to the military. Service: @N286@. Service: Y.

Legatee 14 DEC 1784. Charles County, Maryland, United States of America. Note: named in mother’s will.

Census: 1790 Prince George’s County, Maryland, United States of America. Note: http:/usgwcensus.org/cenfiles/md/princegeorges/1790pg0092.txt. [5] 1800 Port Tobacco Parish, Charles, Maryland, United States of America. Note: "United States Census, 1800," index and images, FamilySearch (https:/familysearch.org/payl:/MM9.1.1XH55-NJR : accessed 01 Mar 2014), Ceasar Richards, 1800. [6]

Buried AFT 3 DEC 1813. Waldorf, Charles, Maryland, United States of America. Note: St. Peter's Old Cemetery. [7]

Occupation: Planter.

Religion: Episcopal.

Notes

Note N284 When was Caesar born? Sources conflict, all seem to be estimated. The *"Revolutionary Patriots of Charles Co., Md.” says Caesar was born 1758-and died Dec. 14, 1813. Heads of fams. At the first U.S. census. Md. By U.S. Bureau of the Census. Washington, 1907. (189p.): 97 put “Cesor’s” birth year at 1750. The 1800 US Census put Caesar’s age at 45+ which puts his birth year at 1755 or earlier.

From Jimmy Yates:

Caesar served as a Private in the Militia, 26th Battalion, Capt. Benjamin Cawood's Company, 1777. He also rendered patriotic service to the revolution by providing wheat for the use of the military in October, 1781 and November, 1782. He was listed as a resident of Port Tobacco East Hundred in 1778.

Burial: Probably buried in St. Peter's Old Cemetery, Waldorf, MD, badly worn stone appears to be Caesar's.

Revolutionary patriots of Charles County, Maryland, 1775-1783 By Henry C. Peden, p. 247 http:/books.google.combooks?id=rCSNb74pjusC&pg=PA247&dq=%22caesar+richards%22+md&client=internal-uds&source=uds#v=onepage&q=&f=false

Richards, Caesar (1758-1813). Private, Militia, 26th Battalion, Capt. Benjamin Cawood’s Company, 1777 [Ref: M-162, which listed the name as “Cigger(?) Richard”]. Resident of Port Tobacco East Hundred in 1778 [Ref: Q-I-297]. He rendered patriotic service by providing wheat for the use of the military in October 1781 and November 1782 [Ref: N-443, N-564]. A son of Thomas Richards and Martha Hoye, Caesar was born in 1758 in Charles County, married Priscilla ----, and died on Dec. 14, 1813. She died on March 19, 1822. Their son Leonard R. Richards (1787-1830) married Christina Montgomery (1786-1858) and lived in Bryantown, Maryland [Ref: S-3138, J-III:2452].

Notes for CAESAR RICHARDS from Alan Albright: From Jimmy Yates: Caesar served as a Private in the Militia, 26th Battalion, Capt. Benjamin Cawood`s Company, 1777. He also rendered patriotic service to the revolution by providing wheat for the use of the military in October, 1781 and November, 1782. "Revolutionary Patriots of Charles County, Maryland 1775-1783" By Henry C. Penden Jr. page 247 He was listed as a resident of Port Tobacco East Hundred in 1778.

Name: CEASAR RICHARDS State: MD County: Charles County Township: Durham Par.East Hun. Year: 1775 Database: MD Early Census Index

Name: CEASAR RICHARDS State: MD County: Charles County Township: Port Tabaccounty East Hct Year: 1778 Record Type: Fidelity Oath Database: MD Early Census Index

Name: Cesor Richards Birth Date: 1750 Birthplace: Maryland Volume: 145 Page Number: 300 Reference: Heads of fams. At the first U.S. census. Md. By U.S. Bureau of the Census. Washington, 1907. (189p.): 97

Caesar was charged in August 1777 of disturbing the peace of the body of Thomas Waters and John Smith. He was convicted in March 1778. Two men, Benjamin Smith and William Richards, pledged security to ensure that the fine would be paid; we assume the William Richards was his Caesar’s brother, but we don’t know who John Smith was. Baseless theories: it was during the time of fidelity oaths and routing out of the Loyalists (my thought and Michael Hait's independently). Perhaps one of them had a sister Priscilla (wouldn't that simplify things--or complicate it, not sure)? Alan and I both independently wondered if perhaps one or both of them commented on the race of his wife and/or kids if Priscilla were Peck. Maybe something entirely more pedestrian like the best police reports on the news with "alcohol may have been involved." There was an Obediah Smith who was a Corporal in the Maryland Loyalists regiment [pp 9 (May 1778) and 111 (September 30th, 1778)]. And a Lt. Col. Wm. S. Smith helped command the Eastern Department May-Oct 1777 (p. 125). No idea yet of any connections. “In May, 1778, [Maryland gentleman James] Chalmers’ regiment was stated to number 336 in all, and it probable that, cut off from its recruiting base by the evacuation of Philadelphia in the next month, it never numbered more.” [partial list of regiment, but commission officers is believed to be complete] p.7 https:/archive.org/detailsorderlybookofmar00mary Orderly book of the "Maryland loyalists regiment," June 18th, 1778, to October 12th, 1778. Including general orders issued by Sir Henry Clinton, Baron Wilhelm von Kuyphausen, Sir William Erskine, Charles, lord Cornwallis, General William Tryon and General Oliver De Lancey. Kept by Captain Caleb Jones by Maryland Loyalists Regiment; Ford, Paul Leicester, 1865-1902, ed; Jones, Caleb, Captain, of Maryland; Historical Printing Club (Brooklyn, New York, N.Y.) Published 1891 Publisher Brooklyn, N.Y., Historical Printing Club

Re: Charles County, Maryland By genealogy.com user May 10, 2000 at 05:29:03 • In reply to: Charles County, Maryland Ted Olmsted 50500

Ted, I am a decendent of the Richards, I will list some information I have. I have included correspondence with others so it doesn't flow well. I do have further information, my email is aalan@@enol.com Alan

Charles Co Wills, 1780-1791

Page 436.Martha Richards, Will. I, Martha Richards of CC, am weak of body but of perfect mind and memory.Firstly, all my debts are to be paid.To my son Thomas Richards - 1 feather bed & furniture, 1 hand mill, 1 gray horse called Silve, 1 large iron pot, and 1 pewter dish. To my son Caesar Richards - 1 feather bed & furniture, 1 gray mare called Starling, and 1 middle sized shallow pewter dish. To my son Richard Richards - 1 Negro girl named Lavina and middle sized deep pewter dish. To my daughter Francess Bean - 7 shillings and 6 pence. To my 3 granddaughters bearing my Christian name - the best of my wearing clothes, to be equally divided between them. To my 4 sons, namely, Thomas, Caeasar, Richard, and William - all my ready cash, with what remains on book, to be equally divided between them. To my son William Richards - my best feather bed and furniture and 1 bay mare and colt and all the crop now made or making, and the rest of my estate.Executors: my sons Thomas and William. Signed Oct 5, 1784 - Martha (X her mark) Richards.Wit - G. Adams, George Adams Jr, Milburn (X his mark) Mahawny. Probated on Dec 14, 1784 by the oaths of both executors and by the oaths of witnesses George Adams Sr, George Adams Jr. and Milburn Mahoney.

I have the children of Caesar Richards as: Richard B., James H. who married Ann Marlow, 20 Dec 1796; Thomas, Gabriel who married Sarah Robey 12 May 1812 in Prince Georges Co., Md.; Leonard Ramsey, b. 1794 and died 7 May 1830- (his tombstone ) another *source says he was born 2 Dec 1787. He married Christina Montgomery; Ann who married Charles Robey; Mary who married Samuel Marlow, 19 Jan 1797; Sarah, b. 19 Aug 1794 and married Thomas Padgett; Delilah;Orphans Court Records, Charles Co. 1823-24, p. 291, Reps of Caesar Richards: Delilah, Richard B., Charles Robey, Elizabeth Montgomery. 1815-1818, p. 560 Accounts & Inventories, Charles Co., Md. Distribution of estate to wife and 8 children, Elizabeth Montgomery, Admin., DBN. There is a good book in the DAR Library called "The Richards Family of Charles Co., Md." by Louise Hancock Graves, July 1978. She has referenced her material. I can't find out where she got Leonard's birthdate which does not match with his tombstone. She has listed the children in the order that I have given them to you. Mary comes before Sarah, b. 1794 - so how could Sarah and Leonard been born in the same year? A source she also used was a "Mudd" Genealogy Book. The *"Revolutionary Patriots of Charles Co., Md." says Caesar was born 1758-and died Dec. 14, 1813. It says his son, Leonard was born 1787 and died 1830. I'm inclined to think that whomever did the tombstones was wrong! The Rev. Patriots book uses as their source: S=Maryland Society, Sons of the American Revolution and J=DAR patriot Index.

Index to register of King George's Parish 1689-1801 > >Leonard Richard b. Dec 2, 1787 son of Cesar and Priscilla >Creacy Richards b. Sep 14, 1792 dau. of Richard and Doratha >James Richards marries Dec 20 1796 toAnn Marlow >James Slow Richards n.(?) Nov 26 1793 son of William & Cloe >Leonard Ranson Richards b. May 7, 1794 son of Ceasar & Priscilla >Mary Richards marries Jan 19 1797 to Samuel Marlow >Reason Richards b. Mar 27, 1796 son of Richard & Doratha >Sarah Ann Richards b.Aug 19, 1794 dau of Samuel & Easter >Wm. Richards marries Jan 24, 1790 Cloe Smawood >William Richards b.Feb 14, 1797 son of William and Chole > >I have left spelling the same as recorded. I also found that a sister >to Caesar Richards, Francis Richards who had married a John Bean, she >names her child Clement Richards Bean >I seem to have seen the name Clement Richards before but can't remember >where.

From Ted, If you look at the account abstract that my Dad made from Caesar's estate, you'll see that Rev. John Weems was paid for the sermon. Rev. Weems was the priest at Port Tobacco Parish, an Episcopal Church. [8]
